content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

You can solve this problem using the `lowercase()` function from Julia's string manipulation utilities, as well as `replace()` for replacing spaces and hyphens. Here is how you could define your function:

```julia
function clean_column(col::String)
    col = lowercase(col)  # Lower case the column name
    col = strip(col)  # Remove leading/trailing whitespaces
    col = replace(col, ' ' => '_')  # Replace spaces with underscores
    col = replace(col, '-' => '_')  # Replace hyphens with underscores
    return col
end
```
This function will take a string input (column name) and return the cleaned version according to your specifications. Please note that Julia is case-sensitive so it treats "my_column" and "My Column" as different strings. If you want them to be treated the same, you should lowercase or uppercase everything before comparison.
